greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 1; a(n) = -Sum_{d|n, d<n} rad(n/d) * a(d), where rad = A007947.
formula: G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = x - Sum_{k>=2} rad(k) * A(x^k).
As lambda(n), h(n), and rad(n) are multiplicative, the identity needs only to be proved for prime power n.

It is clear that the identity holds for n = 1 = p^0. For a given nonnegative integer k, assume the identity holds for all v such that 0 <= v <= k. Then, by the recursive formula for Dirichlet inverses,
Thus the identity holds for p^(k+1), k >= 0.
As k is arbitrary and the identity holds for p^0, it holds for the prime powers, and thus for all positive integers. Q.E.D. (End)
mathematica: a[n_] := If[n == 1, n, -Sum[If[d < n, Last[Select[Divisors[n/d], SquareFreeQ]] a[d], 0], {d, Divisors[n]}]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 60}]
f[p_, e_] := -p*(1 - p)^(e - 1); a[1] = 1; a[n_] := Times @@ (f @@@ FactorInteger[n]); Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Oct 14 2020 *)
program: lista(nn) = {my(va=vector(nn)); va[1] = 1; for (n=2, nn, va[n] = -sumdiv(n, d, if (d<n, rad(n/d) * va[d]));); va;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 01 2020
results.author: _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Sep 04 2019
